grounding: Germ cells are the only cell type that is capable of transmitting genetic information to the next generation, which has enabled the continuation of multicellular life for the last 1.5 billion years. Surprisingly little is known about the mechanisms supporting the germline's remarkable ability to continue in this eternal cycle, termed germline immortality. Even unicellular organisms age at a cellular level, demonstrating that cellular aging is inevitable. Extensive studies in yeast have established the framework of how asymmetric cell division and gametogenesis may contribute to the resetting of cellular age. This review examines the mechanisms of germline immortality—how germline cells reset the aging of cells—drawing a parallel between yeast and multicellular organisms.
generated_text: Asymmetric stem cell division is a critical mechanism that ensures the maintenance of stem cell populations and the generation of differentiated progeny. In the context of germline immortality, this process is particularly vital, as it allows for the perpetuation of genetic information across generations. Recent studies have highlighted the role of ribosomal DNA (rDNA) in regulating asymmetric division and its impact on aging. Specifically, variations in rDNA copy number and transcriptional activity can influence the balance between self-renewal and differentiation, thereby affecting the longevity of germline cells. This review synthesizes current knowledge on the molecular mechanisms underlying asymmetric stem cell division and their implications for germline immortality and aging.
